Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Infrastructure for Collaborative Faculty Textbook Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop infrastructure useful for sharing domain-specific course materials with collaborating Computer Science faculty sharing expertise in a particular domain. The centerpiece of the infrastructure is a free online-textbook; however the infrastructure also includes a membership-controlled area for course materials including projects, homeworks, experience reports, video lectures,
and slides.
This project will advance the state of the art for two relevant Computer Science textbooks, Operating Systems and Introduction to Performance. This content will serve as test material for a more general infrastructure to be developed for the purpose of developing Collaborative Faculty Textbook Communities. They key idea is to use the infrastructure to encourage and ease faculty contribution to, and adoption of, free online textbooks for their courses. The novel aspect is to focus on what the best infrastructure would be for a community of faculty, encouraging the longer-term maintenance and updating of the relevant course materials, and also encourage the participation of faculty with a high level of expertise and limited time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the widespread availability of the internet, and against a backdrop of rising education costs, educators have worked to produce Open Education Resources (OER’s). But open questions remain regarding the best practices and the funding model for development and offering of OERs. Many efforts are ad hoc, and the challenges include is a strong risk of duplication of effort, and also the decreased utility of such materials as they age.

Intellectual Merit.  Our goal was to advance the state of the art for two relevant Computer Science textbooks:  Operating Systems (with a starting point of the current version of Arpaci-Dusseau’s Three Easy Pieces) and Introduction to Performance Measurement, Modeling and Analysis (PMMA) (starting from textbooks fifteen or more years old). The project has resulted in improvements to both areas, including updates to Three Easy Pieces and initial content development of PMMA.  The PMMA materials include current platforms such as clusters and multicore systems, and paradigms such as Map/Reduce. The overarching goal is to use the content development process in the design of more general infrastructure for open educational materials. Towards this goal, a plan for integrating the new performance materials into a free online form has been developed, based on discussions with stakeholders in both the academic and national laboratory environments.

Broader Impacts. PI Karavanic has developed a set of materials for teaching Performance Measurement, Modeling and Analysis; and co-PI Arpaci-Dusseau has updated a set of materials for the online textbook Three Easy Pieces. In addition, they have made progress towards the goal of developing and deploying infrastructure designed to ease the costs (both time and money) of developing and maintaining a free online textbook for a Computer Science course. Making scholarly textbooks and related resources more readily available within the U.S. and beyond has the capability to impact the quality and availability of quality education in Computer Science.  Five Portland State students have participated in, and been supported by, this project as hourly student employees.
